narrative: Meet and confer correspondence with James Clark regarding CCP 430.41 requirement and issues with the complaint in Raj v WFP Hospitality.
subject: SUBJECT OF EMAILRe: Raj v WFP Hospitality
body:
James,

Let's talk on Monday as CCP 430.41 requires that we meet and confer in person or by telephone. I am available after 2 p.m. on Monday. The issues with the complaint pertain to the assault, battery, false imprisonment causes of action which are alleged against the company without any allegations that would cause liability to attach to the company as opposed to Mr. Singh. Workers' compensation is the exclusive remedy for an employee assaulted by another employee: "Thus, we conclude that the exception to the exclusivity rule contained in section 3602, subdivision (b)(1), does not authorize a civil action against an employer for injury resulting from the willful assault of a coemployee based on a theory of respondeat superior." Fretland v. County of Humboldt (1999) 69 Cal.App.4th 1478, 1489. We'd like to avoid the expense of a demurrer and hope that your client will amend the complaint.

Regards,

Dan


Daniel J. Cravens
Fresno Managing Partner

8050 N. Palm Ave. | Suite 300 | Fresno | CA | 93711
DIR 415.604.0142 | CEL 559.472.6584

From: Daniel Cravens <dcravens@ohaganmeyer.com> 
Sent: Friday, August 9, 2024 1:18 PM
To: Nicole Tavis <ntavis@ohaganmeyer.com>
Subject: TGS v. PCC - letter to prepare

 

Nicole, 

 

Would you please put this on letterhead. The correspondence that it responds to is also attached.

 

 

 

Dear Mr. Smith:

 

Our firm represents PCC Logistics and Steve Gardner (“PCC”), who have asked me to respond to your correspondence of July 29, 2024 regarding Mr. Gardners alleged “Theft of TGS Confidential Information and [PCC’s] Interference with TGS Customers.”

Despite its subject line, your correspondence merely identifies quintessential freedom in employment and lawful competition. Both PCC and TGS are family-owned businesses with owners who have been friends for many years. PCC regrets the aggressive tone of your correspondence and hopes to maintain the friendly relationship it has traditionally had with TGS. While PCC has every right to compete in the marketplace, it assures TGS that it has received no confidential information from Mr. Gardner. Furthermore, Mr. Gardner works with a few long-term clients who have remained loyal to him through various employment changes. These customers followed him to TGS and followed him again to PCC as they have every right to do.

Your correspondence fails to identify any property or confidential information that TGS claims Mr. Gardner has misappropriated. Mr. Gardner has taken no confidential information from TGS. Since Mr. Gardner has taken nothing from TGS, there is nothing to return. I assume that if you had any evidence that Mr. Gardner has stolen property from TGS, you would have identified it. Should you have such proof, please provide it. In the meantime, falsely accusing Mr. Gardner of theft is defamation. He is hearing from customers that TGS representatives are making potentially defamatory statements about him. Please advise your client to stop.

Similarly, your correspondence fails to identify any customer that PCC has interfered with nor explained the manner in which it allegedly has interfered with your contracts. Obviously, these customers have a right to work with PCC, TGS, or both of them. Please identify each customer that TGS claims PCC interfered with, the manner in which TGS claims that PCC violated competition law, and your evidence supporting this allegation.

If you have some specifics of unlawful activity by any PCC employee, please provide them to me. PCC will address the issue without the need for litigation. But I advise caution. As we both know, unfair competition cases are expensive, disruptive to business, and often lead to outcomes that only benefit the lawyers. If TGS files an unfair competition lawsuit without any evidence of wrongdoing, PCC has authorized me to respond aggressively including by filing an anti-slapp motion seeking sanctions.

Respectfully,

Dan

 

 

 

Daniel J. Cravens
Fresno Managing Partner

8050 N. Palm Ave. | Suite 300 | Fresno | CA | 93711
DIR 415.604.0142 | CEL 559.472.6584

 <https://ohaganmeyer.com/>

From: Daniel Cravens <dcravens@ohaganmeyer.com>
Sent: Thursday, July 25, 2024 3:08 PM
To: lawyerym@hotmail.com <lawyerym@hotmail.com>
Subject: Wang et al. v. Harris et al. (Case No. CIVSB2412923) 
 

Dear Ms. Yu,

 

I am writing to meet and confer as required by CCP section 431.30 concerning the second and third cases of action alleged against Sanchez, Ortiz, and Real in the hope of avoiding a demurrer.

 

These causes of action depend on a fiduciary relationship between Real and its agents on the one hand and Plaintiff on the other.  However, the complaint discloses that no such relationship existed.

*	Paragraph 16 avers that Harris filed a Partition Complaint against your client for division of the property and obtained a default judgment against your client.
*	Paragraph 18 avers that the Court appointed an elisor to act on behalf of your client.
*	Paragraph 19 avers that the Plaintiff applied for relief ex parte which the Court denied.

The allegation that the property was sold pursuant to a court partition order and after the appointment of an elisor establishes that there can be no breach of fiduciary relationship or breach of duty of care by Real and its agents.

 

Moreover, the allegation that your client reposed “repos[ed] trust and confidence in Defendants in connection with listing of the Property (¶ 46) is directly contradicted by the allegation that your client was “unaware of the Property’s sale until March 8th, 2024.”  The allegation that your client reposed trust in Real and its agents is false and brought in bad faith.

 

We would like to avoid unnecessary expenditure of fees bringing a demurrer and 128.7 motion. Do you have time to discuss this matter next week? I have broad availability on July 30 and July 31.

 

Regards,

 

Dan 

 

 

Daniel J. Cravens
Fresno Managing Partner

8050 N. Palm Ave. | Suite 300 | Fresno | CA | 93711
DIR 415.604.0142 | CEL 559.472.6584

narrative: Prepare letter in response to correspondence regarding alleged theft and interference with TGS Confidential Information and PCC's Interference with TGS Customers
subject: SUBJECT OF EMAILTGS v. PCC - letter to prepare
body:
Nicole, 

Would you please put this on letterhead. The correspondence that it responds to is also attached.

 
 
Dear Mr. Smith:
 
Our firm represents PCC Logistics and Steve Gardner (“PCC”), who have asked me to respond to your correspondence of July 29, 2024 regarding Mr. Gardners alleged “Theft of TGS Confidential Information and [PCC’s] Interference with TGS Customers.”
Despite its subject line, your correspondence merely identifies quintessential freedom in employment and lawful competition. Both PCC and TGS are family-owned businesses with owners who have been friends for many years. PCC regrets the aggressive tone of your correspondence and hopes to maintain the friendly relationship it has traditionally had with TGS. While PCC has every right to compete in the marketplace, it assures TGS that it has received no confidential information from Mr. Gardner. Furthermore, Mr. Gardner works with a few long-term clients who have remained loyal to him through various employment changes. These customers followed him to TGS and followed him again to PCC as they have every right to do.
Your correspondence fails to identify any property or confidential information that TGS claims Mr. Gardner has misappropriated. Mr. Gardner has taken no confidential information from TGS. Since Mr. Gardner has taken nothing from TGS, there is nothing to return. I assume that if you had any evidence that Mr. Gardner has stolen property from TGS, you would have identified it. Should you have such proof, please provide it. In the meantime, falsely accusing Mr. Gardner of theft is defamation. He is hearing from customers that TGS representatives are making potentially defamatory statements about him. Please advise your client to stop.
Similarly, your correspondence fails to identify any customer that PCC has interfered with nor explained the manner in which it allegedly has interfered with your contracts. Obviously, these customers have a right to work with PCC, TGS, or both of them. Please identify each customer that TGS claims PCC interfered with, the manner in which TGS claims that PCC violated competition law, and your evidence supporting this allegation.
If you have some specifics of unlawful activity by any PCC employee, please provide them to me. PCC will address the issue without the need for litigation. But I advise caution. As we both know, unfair competition cases are expensive, disruptive to business, and often lead to outcomes that only benefit the lawyers. If TGS files an unfair competition lawsuit without any evidence of wrongdoing, PCC has authorized me to respond aggressively including by filing an anti-slapp motion seeking sanctions.
Respectfully,
Dan
 
 


Daniel J. Cravens
Fresno Managing Partner

8050 N. Palm Ave. | Suite 300 | Fresno | CA | 93711
DIR 415.604.0142 | CEL 559.472.6584

 <https://ohaganmeyer.com/>

narrative: Review and revise draft response to TGS regarding potential litigation
subject: SUBJECT OF EMAILTGS v. PCC
body:
All--

Please find the attached draft response to TGS. I've intentionally adopted a restrained tone in the hope that we can avoid litigation. I can make the tone more aggressive if you prefer. This kind of litigation is expensive and disruptive. I spoke with Steve today who confirmed that he neither has confidential TGS information nor has he given such to PCC. Moreover, he confirmed that he is currently only working with four customers that he's had for decades. I don't see the basis of an unfair competition claim. I think they would have given us evidence if any existed. 

I'll send this out later today unless I receive some comments from you.

Warmly,

Dan


Daniel J. Cravens
Fresno Managing Partner
